name.text: 25.3.2.4 Method of separation of variables - general approach

questiontext.text:
Laplace’s equation
\(\qquad\displaystyle \dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}+\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial y^2}=0\) \((9)\)

Example

Separating the variables for Laplace’s equation follows similar lines to the previous Example. Obtain the ODEs satisfied by \(X(x)\) and \(Y(y)\).

Solution

Assuming \(u(x, y) = X(x)Y(y)\) leads to: \(\displaystyle \dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}=X''Y\) \(\qquad\displaystyle \dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial y^2}=XY''\) so

\(\qquad X''Y + XY''=0\) \(\qquad\) or \(\qquad\) \(\dfrac{X''}{X}=-\dfrac{Y''}{Y}\)
Equating each side to a constant \(K\)

\(\qquad \dfrac{X''}{X}=K\)\(\qquad\) or\(\qquad\) \(\displaystyle \frac{\mathrm{d^2}X}{\mathrm{d}x^2}-KX=0\) \((10a)\)
\(\qquad \dfrac{Y''}{Y}=-K\)\(\qquad\) or\(\qquad\)\(\displaystyle \frac{\mathrm{d^2}Y}{\mathrm{d}y^2}+KY=0\) \((10b)\)

(Note carefully the different signs in the two ODEs. Yet again the sign of the “separation constant” \(K\) will determine the solutions.)
